awd_titl_txt: Bridge to the Doctorate: Wisconsin Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The ability of the United States to protect its national interests and remain competitive on a global scale requires a domestic workforce with advanced degree training in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). Yet, graduate education in STEM is marked by a persistent absence of certain ethnic/racial groups and in some disciplines women of all backgrounds. Despite the need for diverse researchers, many excellent students from backgrounds that are underrepresented in STEM begin their graduate studies in a STEM discipline, but leave before completing their degrees. The Wisconsin Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation Bridge to the Doctorate (WiscAMP-BD) Cohort 1 project addressed the need to increase the diversity of an advanced degree STEM workforce by:

  • Recruiting a cohort of 12 excellent students who graduated with baccalaureate degrees in STEM from Louis Stokes Alliance from Minority Participation institutions across the country
  • Pairing students with experienced faculty advisors who have robust research programs and are committed to supporting students with mentorship and research funding through five years of graduate study
  • Providing professional development seminars, social opportunities with a diverse community of peers, and access to a network of culturally responsive faculty mentors

At the end of its award period, the WiscAMP-BD Cohort 1 project has successfully retained 10 out of 12 underrepresented minority students in STEM doctoral training programs. Two students completed their Master’s Degrees (one in Civil Engineering and one in Forest and Wildlife Ecology) with commitments from their faculty advisors to support the students should they choose to resume their graduate studies. One student completed her Master’s degree in Pharmaceutical Science and transferred to continue her doctorate in chemical biology at another institution.

Of the 10 students who remain in doctoral programs, two were successful in obtaining prestigious research fellowships beyond the Bridge to the Doctorate. One student in Biomedical Engineering was selected for a National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship. Another student in the Neuroscience Training Program was awarded the National Institutes of Health (NIH) Ruth L. Kirschstein Pre-doctoral Individual National Research Service Award (NRSA) award. One student in Engineering Physics was selected for an internship with Oak Ridge National Laboratory. A student in the Chemistry doctoral program was first author on a featured research article published in the lead journal for her discipline. Two additional students were also successful in publishing articles in peer-reviewed journals. These are notable accomplishments for students early in their graduate careers.

Broader Impacts: The WiscAMP-BD Cohort 1 outcomes reflect the collective commitment of faculty, graduate training program staff and administrative leadership to the national effort to broaden participation in STEM and diversity the professoriate. The collaborations between programs, faculty and staff have led to more integrated and consistent professional development opportunities across graduate training programs. The long-term outcome of the WiscAMP-BD program will be to increase the ethnic/racial diversity of leaders throughout academic science and engineering.  Increasing the diversity of academic leadership will promote greater diversity in all STEM areas and foster research excellence and innovation.

Intellectual Merit: The WiscAMP-BD project included an evaluation component that provided valuable evidence of the importance of programs to retain underrepresented minority students in STEM graduate programs. A survey of students who were participating in WiscAMP-BD and similar programs found that minority graduate students in these programs were more likely than their counterparts to believe they belonged in their discipline and to value the importance of ethnic and gender diversity in their field of research. These results are consistent with attitudes and beliefs that will lead to persistence in research career pathways and have been disseminated at regional and national conferences.

 


Last Modified: 07/09/2018
Modified by: Gail Coover
